info.game_comments:
2000-B College Championship quarterfinal game 1.  
From the University of Washington in Seattle.

(1, 1).clue: Daniel Defoe claimed that this shipwreck classic was an allegory of his own life

(2, 1).clue: A 100-foot-tall Coke bottle adorns a mall in front of the MGM Grand Hotel in this city

(4, 1).clue: It has the shortest name of the 7 continents

(6, 1).clue: This man's story begins in Genesis 1:26

(1, 2).clue: This 1961 novel by Joseph Heller takes place on the island of Pianosa

(2, 2).clue: Bodie, California, this type of abandoned "town", features 170 buildings in a state of "arrested decay"

(4, 2).clue: The number of eyes visible on the back of the U.S. $1 bill

(6, 2).clue: "Come Together" is one of many biographies about this late rock legend

(1, 3).clue: If you're from Narnia, you may know this author wrote some poetry under the pen name Clive Hamilton

(2, 3).clue: A long, lit-up "M" marks the Hernando de Soto Bridge that crosses this river at Memphis

(4, 3).clue: Currently, the only 2 countries in the world that begin with the letter Z

(6, 3).clue: "The Last Lion" is William Manchester's bestselling bio of this WWII British prime minister

(1, 4).clue: This lyrical drama by Percy Shelley takes license with Aeschylus' "Prometheus Bound"

(2, 4).clue: In 1946 a chain of convenience stores in Texas adopted this name to reflect the hours they were open

(4, 4).clue: They're the 2 of Snow White's 7 dwarves whose names don't end in "Y"

(6, 4).clue: Smile!  "Historian with a Camera" is a 1955 biography of this famous Civil War photographer

(1, 5).clue: This "Wilde" guy gives his soul to remain young while his picture reflects his descent into debauchery

(2, 5).clue: See experts at the Smithsonian work on the conservation of the Star-Spangled Banner from this fort

(4, 5).clue: By last name, he's alphabetically last on a list of U.S. presidents

(5, 5).clue: Enrollment record keeper at a university(9)

(6, 5).clue: "The World at His Fingertips" tells the story of this handicapped Frenchman

(1, 1).clue: The trident on Barbados' flag stands for this Roman god of the sea

(2, 1).clue: Before "The Matrix" he debuted as a goalie in the hockey film "Youngblood"

(3, 1).clue: John Smeaton, the first to call himself a civil engineer, built one of these ship-guiding structures near Plymouth

(4, 1).clue: This nosy, long-tailed critter is the only marsupial found in the U.S.

(5, 1).clue: A variation of couch potato, a mouse potato is someone who spends a lot of time with this

(6, 1).clue: She plotted against the French Revolution & gave military secrets to her brother Leopold II of Austria

(1, 2).clue: This nation's area consists of about 44% of all the land area in the West Indies

(2, 2).clue: He was just 14 (& not yet married to Uma Thurman) when he debuted in "Explorers" in 1985

(3, 2).clue: Name shared by a tunnel-digging machine & a mammal with poor eyesight

(4, 2).clue: While true buffaloes have 13 pairs of ribs, this American counterpart has 14

(5, 2).clue: Like Carson Daly of MTV, a TV host who plays musical clips or images is known by this "initial" term

(6, 2).clue: On November 15, 1920 the League of Nations held its first meeting in this city

(1, 3).clue: Duarte Peak, the highest point in the West Indies, rises 10,417 feet in this nation that occupies 2/3 of Hispaniola

(2, 3).clue: She debuted as a lovesick teen in 1991's "The Man in the Moon"; in 1999 she was up for "Election"

(3, 3).clue: Malaria killed many workers on the Rideau one of these, though it's in Canada, not Panama

(4, 3).clue: The basilisk, which can run short distances over water, is a type of this creature

(5, 3).clue: Also a term in census taking, it's borrowing an old piece of music & using it in a new song; try it!

(6, 3).clue: In 1968 Soviet troops invaded this country & abducted Communist Party leader Alexander Dubcek

(1, 4).clue: The College of the Bahamas, that nation's only school of higher learning, is located in this capital city

(2, 4).clue: This talk show host was a student at Ithaca College when she won the lead in "Hairspray"

(3, 4).clue: The 40-mile-long Old Croton one of these was completed in 1842 -- but that's all water over the bridge

(4, 4).clue: The 2 African species of the mammal seen here have these contrasting names

(5, 4).clue: From the title of a 1990 Martin Scorsese film, it's a popular term for mobsters

(6, 4).clue: In the 4th century Greece became a part of the Byzantine Empire; about 1,100 years later it became part of this empire

(1, 5).clue: Once known as St. Christopher and Nevis, it's now known by this slightly shorter name

(2, 5).clue: "Purple People Eater" introduced this young star who played Kevin Spacey's daughter in "American Beauty"

(3, 5).clue: Beginning in 1824 Congress allowed this military group to take on civilian projects

(4, 5).clue: The rough skin of these fish that make up the order Selachii was once made into a type of sandpaper called shagreen

(5, 5).clue: For politicians this medical-sounding spokesperson makes the bad news all better

(6, 5).clue: In the 1200s this western Italian city-state ruled the central Mediterranean, including Sardinia & Corsica

(0, 0).clue: The first NBA playoff game outside the United States was played in this city
